page.title: 02Lydiard Millicent
page.content: The village of Lydiard Millicent is believed to be{Saxon}in origin the name Lydiard probably being derived from the Saxon for boundary. The word Millicent comes from a{Lady Millicent who gained possession of the village after the Norman Conquest . The 15th century{All Saints church built of limestone is in the centre of the village and behind it is situated the new{manor}built on the ruins of the original Tudor structure which was burnt to the ground in 1880. For many hundreds of years the village was a very poor community and only recovered with the coming of the {railway}to{Swindon,}the villages prosperty being linked with that of the nearby town. Consequently most of the older houses in the village are fairly small and simple including some built in a day on common land .
